I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Pakistan (GOP) has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
to provide project preparatory technical assistance (TA) for developing renewable energy (RE).  
A TA Fact-Finding Mission visited Pakistan 21–30 July 2004 to formulate the proposed TA and 
reached an understanding with GOP on the purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, cost 
estimates, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for consultants.1   The TA is included 
in the Country Strategy and Program Update (CSPU) 2004–2006. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Pakistan is a net importer of energy.  Each year it spends $3 billion, equivalent to about 
30% of total imports, to import oil to meet its energy needs. Oil importation is a heavy burden on 
GOP’s foreign exchange.  Recent increases in oil prices and their continuous fluctuation further 
complicate this problem. Most of the imported energy is for electricity generation.  Over 70% of 
Pakistan’s electricity comes from thermal sources, a little less than 30% from hydro, and less 
than  1%  from  renewable  and  other  sources.  Even  with  all  this imported  energy,  Pakistan 
currently faces a 20% power shortage.  Only 55% of Pakistan’s population have access to 
electricity from the national grid.  The remaining 45% use kerosene, wood, and other bio-fuels 
for  lighting,  cooking,  and  heating.    In  fact,  Pakistan  has  one  of  the  lowest  per  capita 
consumption of energy in the world.     
 
3.  To address the energy shortage and as part of its decentralization policy, GOP has 
delegated authority to the provinces to develop their own generating capacity of up to 50 
megawatts (MW) to meet their energy needs2. Installation of small-scale power generation 
technologies located close to the load being served, or distributed generation, has significant 
advantages.  It will not only help meet the power shortage, but also ensure greater power 
reliability and quality.  
 
4.  GOP has decided to put greater emphasis on RE. In May 2003, it announced that it had 
set a target of 10% RE, or 2,700 MW, of the country’s energy mix by 20153 and established the 
Alternative Energy Development Board (AEDB) as the apex organization to coordinate RE 
promotion.  To underscore the importance of this initiative, AEDB reports directly to the Prime 
Minister and sits in the Prime Minister’s Secretariat.  Pakistan’s RE potential is substantial and 
the vast majority of it remains untapped.  Its hydro potential from run-of-the-river micro, mini, 
and small hydro schemes4 from perennial streams, and the extensive irrigation canal system 
have not yet been fully measured.5  However, this potential has already proven successful both 
in small communities and for connection to the national grid.  Pakistan’s potential for wind has 
not yet been fully measured, but GOP has installed 50 towers, 30–100 feet high, in the coastal 
areas of Sindh and Balochistan and the desert of Balochistan, to measure wind velocity.  Data 
gathered over the past 2 years indicate that there is adequate wind velocity for setting up wind 
turbines.  The potential for solar energy, although not yet determined, is also thought to be very 
good.

 5.  ADB has given Pakistan assistance on RE through TA 5972: Promoting Renewable 
Energy, Energy Efficiency, and Greenhouse Gas Abatement (PREGA).6  PREGA consultants 
produced a substantive report on GOP’s policies on RE, identifying specific incentives and 
barriers that are currently in place for RE development.  The PREGA consultants are also 
currently finalizing two reports.  One will recommend additional policies and incentives that can 
be implemented to promote RE and the other will recommend steps that need to be taken to 
establish the necessary structure to take advantage of the clean development mechanism 
(CDM)7 of the Kyoto Protocols to promote further RE development.   
 
6.  Currently,  there  are  a  few  market-based  and  fiscal  incentives  for  RE,  such  as 
accelerated depreciation for investors and low import duties and taxes for RE technologies 
already in place in Pakistan.  However, experience around the world indicates that unless equal 
opportunities are made available to conventional energy (mainly thermal power from oil or coal) 
and RE, the establishment of RE will be very difficult and GOP will not be able to meet its goal 
of 10% of its energy mix from RE sources.  For example, there are hidden subsidies on the fuel 
costs for conventional power generation that allow for lower generation costs.  In addition, costs 
of environmental externalities from pollution have not been included in the pricing of power from 
conventional power generation. AEDB is preparing several additional market-based incentives 
such as the introduction of tax holidays, further reducing import duties on a greater range of 
technologies, etc. to attract investments in RE and establishment of RE manufacturing facilities 
in Pakistan. AEDB is also working on a pricing structure for RE, based on the costs and benefits 
of RE, that will allow it to compete with generation from conventional energy. The PREGA 
reports, as well as AEDB’s ongoing efforts to introduce market-based and pricing incentives for 
RE, will serve as the basis for policy dialogue with GOP on promoting RE.   
  
7.   ADB has also assisted the National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA).8  
NEPRA was created in 1997 and is charged with establishing a regulatory regime that would 
enable and facilitate the transition of the electricity supply industry in Pakistan to commercial 
operation  and,  ultimately,  private  participation  in  ownership.    The  current  structure  for  the 
electricity market is a Single Buyer Plus model where the National Transmission and Despatch 
Company (NTDC) buys all energy from the electricity generators and sells the power to the 
distribution companies.  The model also has provisions that allow distribution companies to 
contract directly with generators through a direct bilateral contract, with NTDC serving as the 
transmission company.  The licensing arrangements are already in place to have provincial 
governments serving as, what would effectively be, independent power producers or generation 
companies selling electricity to NTDC or directly to distribution companies. 
 
8.  The promotion of RE is consistent with ADB's energy policy (2000), which emphasizes 
the importance of addressing the local, regional and global environmental impacts of ADB’s 
energy sector interventions in developing member countries (DMCs).  The TA is also consistent 
with the objectives of the energy sector in the CSPU 2004–2006 which, among others, is to 
provide strategic support for greater use of indigenous energy sources.  ADB has also assisted

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Outputs 
 
9.  The  TA  will  prepare  a  project  to  develop  indigenous,  nonpolluting,  and  renewable 
sources of energy to help meet Pakistan’s power shortage and improve the quality and reliability 
of the power system, especially in rural areas.  The TA outputs will be the following studies, 
analyses, and reports: (i) analysis of the RE potential of each province, and (ii) feasibility studies 
of selected sample subprojects for financing under the ensuing loan.  The TA framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The TA will have two components.   
 
(i)  Component 1-Review of renewable energy potential in each province. A 
broad review of the potential for various RE technologies in each province will be 
conducted to determine the most appropriate (i.e., technically and economically 
viable) sub-projects suitable for funding by the ensuing loan.  The TA will focus 
on specific RE technologies in each province: (a) Balochistan: wind, solar, and 
hybrid systems; (b) North-West Frontier Province (NWFP): small hydropower 
from perennial high-head rivers that are abundant in the province; (c) Punjab: 
low-head, high-volume small hydropower stations that can be installed in the 
extensive irrigation canal system in perennial flow in the province; and (d) Sindh: 
small hydro, wind, solar, as well as hybrid systems.  It is expected that 30% of 
the TA resources will be committed to this component. 
 
(ii)  Component 2-Feasibility studies. Based on the reviews, the TA consultants 
will work with the implementing agencies (IAs) to prioritize subprojects in each 
province.   The  subprojects  will  be  selected  by  least-cost  analysis  for  power 
system expansion, consistent with ADB’s energy policy (2000), and will include 
analysis  of  alternatives,  as  well  as  conventional  energy  sources.  The  TA 
consultants  will  then  conduct  feasibility  studies  for  sample  projects  in  each 
province  (about  2  per  province)  to  be  financed  by  the  ensuing  loan.  The 
feasibility studies will include technical, economic, financial,9 environmental, and 
social analyses.  The ensuing loan is expected to be a sector loan.  As such, the 
feasibility studies will develop model technical, economic, and financial analyses 
that can be used by the executing agencies (EAs) in selecting subprojects for 
loan financing as well as framework for environmental and social assessments. It 
is expected that 70% the TA resources will be committed to this component.   
                                  
 
9 ADB has a CDM facility.  The executing agencies (EAs) may want to request assistance from the ADB CDM facility 
to explore the possibility of developing the CDM components of the subprojects to generate an additional income 
stream.  However, Pakistan has not yet ratified the Kyoto Protocols.

4  
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The total cost of the proposed TA is estimated at $800,000 equivalent, comprising about 
$380,000 in foreign exchange cost and about $420,000 equivalent in local currency cost. ADB 
will provide $550,000, comprising $380,000 in foreign exchange cost and $170,000 equivalent 
in local currency cost on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government 
of Japan.  The Government will contribute the remaining $250,000 equivalent of the local 
currency costs in kind.  The cost estimates are in Appendix 2.  The Government has been 
advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing ensuing projects.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  AEDB  will  be  the  EA  for  the  TA.    Its  role  will  be  to  facilitate  TA  implementation, 
coordinate its activities, and disseminate the information learned.  The TA will be implemented 
at the provincial level.  The IAs will be the Department of Irrigation and Power of each province.  
The departments will work closely with the TA consultants and will provide them with the 
necessary information and guidance in carrying out the studies.  A project manager of senior 
standing  in  the  IA  will  be  appointed  by  the  IAs,  and  a  project  management  unit  (PMU), 
consisting of two or three engineers, will be established in each province to oversee the day-to-
day activities and work with the project consultants.  The project manager will be appointed and 
PMU established before the TA begins.   
 
13.  The TA will be implemented in four phases:  phase 1, inception phase; phase 2, review 
of the potential for various RE technologies in each province as outlined in component 1; phase 
3, conducting required studies and analyses as outlined in component 2; and phase 4, finalizing 
the feasibility studies and reports.   The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an 
inception report to be submitted 1 month after project start-up, providing a detailed work plan for 
implementing the TA; (ii) an interim report after completion of phase 2, with the review of the 
potential for various RE technologies in each province; (iii) an interim report after completion of 
phase 3, with the findings of the required studies, analyses, models, and reports; and (iv) a final 
report that meets the requirements of ADB’s sector loan modality.  All major draft reports will be 
circulated to the IAs, ADB, and relevant stakeholders. All project reports will be drafted in a 
manner  consistent  with  documentation  needed  for  processing  an  ADB  sector  loan.  The 
consultants will then organize a consultation or tripartite meeting of representatives from the 
IAs, AEDB, ADB, and relevant stakeholders, including concerned ministries, departments, and 
agencies  of  the  federal  and  provincial  governments,  nongovernment  organizations,  private 
entrepreneurs, external funding agencies, etc.  The meetings will be held in Pakistan, 1 week 
after circulation of the draft reports to discuss the findings. The team leader will submit a final 
report within 1 month of the final consultation or tripartite meeting, incorporating comments 
during the meetings. 
 
14.  The TA will begin in January 2005. It will be carried out over 8 months and will be 
completed by 30 September 2005.  The TA will require 14 person-months of international and 
32 person-months of domestic consulting services.  The consultants will have prior experience 
in preparing an ADB sector loan and be familiar with ADB’s respective guidelines for technical, 
financial, and economic analyses, as well as environmental and social safeguards. The outline 
terms of reference for consulting services are in Appendix 3.  Consultants will be selected in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for engaging of domestic consultants.  The consultants will be required to 
submit simplified technical proposals and will be selected using the quality- and cost-based

method.    Procurement  of  any  equipment  under  the  TA  will  follow  ADB’s  Guidelines  on 
Procurement. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $550,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for preparing the Renewable Energy Development Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.   International Consultants 
 
1.  A total of 14 person-months of international consulting services will be required for the 
technical assistance (TA). 
 
1.  Hydropower Engineer - Team Leader (5 person-months)  
 
2.  The  hydropower  engineer  will  also  function  as  the  team  leader  for  the  TA  since  
hydropower is expected to be the largest component of the TA and the ensuing loan. The 
consultant will be internationally recruited1 and should (i) have demonstrated experience in 
overseeing the design and implementation of small hydro projects; (ii) be familiar with multiple 
aspects  of  several  other  renewable  energies  (REs)  such  as  wind,  solar  photovoltaic  (PV) 
systems, and wind-solar hybrid systems; and (iii) have extensive experience leading multi-
cultural and multidisciplinary teams.  The consultant will save 0.75 person-month of his or her 
time to assist the Asian Development Bank (ADB) during loan processing. 
 
3.  For project management, the team leader is expected to (i) be the primary contact for all 
matters  related  to  the  project,  including  technical,  communications,  administrative,  etc.;  (ii) 
supervise the consulting team members to ensure their performance and timely completion of 
tasks; (iii) prepare the required reports as outlined in the reporting requirements of this terms of 
reference (TOR); (iv) review and edit all reports to ensure that they are of the highest quality; 
and (v) assist in preparing the loan documents. 
 
4.    As hydropower engineer, the consultant will (i) develop criteria for selecting the sample 
projects and review the technical aspects of the feasibility studies prepared by the implementing 
agencies (IAs); (ii) conduct a technology review to introduce the latest available technologies 
regarding plant design, turbines, and electromechanical technologies; (iii) ensure that the civil 
works design, load control systems, transmission and distribution network, and technology used 
are appropriate for the specific hydropower application to ensure maximum production efficiency 
at the least possible cost; (iv) from the reviews, develop specific technical criteria for subprojects 
chosen for funding and implementation by the follow-on loan; (v) work with the economist to 
ensure  that  the  selected  subprojects  are  based  on  least-cost  analysis  for  power  system 
expansion, consistent with ADB’s energy policy (2000);  (vi) ensure that the subprojects are 
designed  to  operate  within  the  existing  regulatory  framework;  (vii)  prepare  the  Planning 
Commission Form I (PC-I) documents for approval of the Government of Pakistan (GOP); (viii) 
prepare  draft  bidding  documents  for  international  competitive  bidding  (ICB)  and  local 
competitive bidding (LCB) contracts, based on ADB’s standard templates to be used by the IAs; 
and  (ix)  prepare  terms  of  reference  (TOR)  for  consultants  to  assist  the  IAs  during  loan 
implementation. 
 
2.  Renewable Energy Specialist (2.5 person-months) 
 
5.  The specialist will be internationally recruited, and have demonstrated experience in 
overseeing the design and implementation of a variety of renewable energy projects such as 
wind, solar PV, and hybrid projects. The consultant will (i) develop criteria for selecting the 
sample projects and review the technical aspects of the feasibility studies prepared by the IAs;

standard templates to be used by the IAs; and (vii) assist in preparing TOR for consultants to

3.  Economist (2.5 person-months)  
 
6.  The  economist  will  be  internationally  recruited,  and  have  an  advanced  degree  in 
economics and significant and demonstrable experience in preparing economic models for 
sector loans in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. The 
economist will save 0.5 person- month of his or her time to help ADB make necessary changes 
to the economic and financial analyses during loan processing.  The consultant will take the 
lead in (i) working with the domestic economist to collect the necessary information and conduct 
the economic analysis (including analysis of alternative needs, identification and measurement 
of economic benefits on a with- and without-project basis); sensitivity analyses; sustainability 
analysis (with examination of financial, fiscal, and institutional implications), ensuring that the 
subprojects selected are the basis of least-cost analysis for power system expansion, consistent 
with ADB’s energy policy (2000); and calculation of the economic internal rate of return (EIRR); 
(ii) developing an economic model that can be used by the IAs for the follow-on loan and 
training the IAs on how to use the model; (iii) developing a handbook of the procedures and 
methodologies  for  subproject  economic  analysis;  (iv),  reviewing  the  current  regulations  on 
independent power producers (IPPs), and assist in developing a sample PPA for use by the 
subprojects; and (v) if necessary, prepare TOR of consulting services that will be needed for the 
ensuing loan.   
 
7.  The consultant should also have experience with financial modeling and ADB sector 
loan  requirements  in  accordance  with  the  Guidelines  for  the  Financial  Governance  and 
Management of Investment Projects Financed by the Asian Development Bank.  The consultant 
will  also  work  with  the  domestic  financial  analyst  to  (i)  collect  the  necessary  information, 
undertake  financial  analysis,  and  calculate  the  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR);  (ii) 
develop a financial model that can be used by the IAs for the follow-on loan and the IAs on how 
to  use  the model;  and  (iii)  develop  a  handbook  of  the  procedures  and  methodologies  for 
subproject financial analysis. 
 
4.  Environmental Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
8.  The specialist will be internationally recruited, and with significant and demonstrable 
experience in developing framework environmental impact assessments (EIAs) for ADB sector 
loan modality. The consultant will take the lead in the following tasks: (i) review the sample initial 
environmental  examinations  (IEEs)  prepared  by  the  domestic  environmental  specialist  and 
prepare an IEE framework with environmental management plan (or EIA, if necessary) for the 
subprojects in accordance with ADB’s (a) environmental assessment guidelines (2003), and (b) 
Environmental  Guidelines  for  Selected  Infrastructure  Development  Projects;  (ii)  prepare  a 
summary IEE (or EIA) for ADB loan processing; (iii) conduct an institutional analysis of the 
relevant IAs to ensure that they have the necessary capacity to conduct the EIAs for the

Appendix 3  11 
subprojects; (iv) provide a training course and handbook of the procedures and methodologies 
for subproject EIAs; and (v) assist in preparing TOR of  consulting services that will be needed 
for the ensuing loan. 
 
5.  Social Development Specialist (2 person-months)  
 
9.  The specialist will be internationally recruited, and have significant and demonstrable 
experience working on developing a framework for social and indigenous peoples (S and IP) 
analysis and involuntary resettlement plans. The consultant will (i) review the sample S and IP 
analysis  and  involuntary  resettlement  plan  (if  necessary)  prepared  by  the  domestic  social 
development specialist, and prepare a framework S and IP plan and involuntary resettlement 
plan (if necessary) to be used for the subprojects; (ii) examine the affected communities in the 
subproject areas for ethnic and cultural minorities; (iii) submit an IP categorization form which 
should indicate the significance of project impact on ethnic and cultural minorities; (iv) prepare 
summary S and IP, and a resettlement plan for loan processing; (v) conduct an institutional 
analysis of the relevant IAs to ensure that they have the capacity to implement S and IP and 
involuntary resettlement plans (if necessary) for the subprojects; (vi) provide a training course 
and handbook of the procedures and methodologies for subproject social development and 
involuntary resettlement plans; and (vii) assist in preparing TOR for consulting services that will 
be needed for the ensuing loan. 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants  
10.  The TA is expected to need a total of 32 person-months of domestic consulting services. 
 
1.  Hydropower Engineer (5 person-months)  
11.  The consultant will have significant experience working with small hydro applications in 
Pakistan.  The consultant will (i) take the lead in all aspects of the hydropower sector especially 
in collecting and analyzing data;  (ii) assist the team leader - hydropower engineer in developing 
criteria for selecting the sample subprojects; (iii) conduct the necessary fieldwork to review the 
feasibility  studies;  and  (iv)  assist  the  team  leader  in  developing  the  technical  criteria  for 
subprojects that can be funded by the follow-on loan. 
 
2.  Wind Power Engineer (4 person-months)  
12.  The consultant will have significant experience working with wind power applications in 
Pakistan.  The consultant will (i) take the lead in all aspects of the wind sector, especially, 
collecting and analyzing of data; (ii) help the team leader and the renewable energy specialist 
develop criteria for selecting the sample subprojects; (iii) conduct the necessary fieldwork to 
review the feasibility studies; and (iv) help assist the team leader develop the technical criteria 
for subprojects that can be funded by the follow-on loan.   
 
3.  Solar Power Engineer (4 person-months) 
13.  The  consultant  will  have  significant  experience  working  with  solar  applications  in 
Pakistan.  The consultant will (i) take the lead in all aspects of the solar sector, especially 
collecting and analyzing data; (ii) help the team leader and the renewable energy specialist 
develop criteria for selecting the sample subprojects; (iii) conduct the necessary fieldwork to 
review the feasibility studies; and (iv) help the team leader develop the technical criteria for 
subprojects that can be funded by the follow-on loan.

12  Appendix 3 
4.  Economist (5 person-months)  
 
14.  The  consultant  will  have  significant  experience  working  with  energy  projects.  The 
consultant will (i) take the lead in gathering data, conducting the necessary fieldwork, and 
undertaking economic analysis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis 
of Projects; (ii) help the international economist develop the model for the EIRR, develop the 
training manual, and train the IAs on the use of the model; and (iii) calculate EIRRs for the 
subprojects to be financed by the follow-on loan. 
 
5.  Financial Analyst (5 person-months)   
 
15.  The  consultant  will  have  significant  experience  working  with  energy  projects.  The 
consultant will (i) take the lead in gathering data, conducting the necessary fieldwork, and 
undertaking financial analysis in accordance with the Guidelines for the Financial Governance 
and Management of Investment Projects Financed by the Asian Development Bank; (ii) help the 
international economist develop the model for the FIRR, develop the training manual, and  train 
the IAs on the use of the model; and (iii) calculate FIRRs for the subprojects to be financed by 
the follow-on loan.  
 
6.  Environmental Specialist (4.5 person-months) 
 
16.  The  consultant  will  have  significant  experience  conducting  EIAs  in  Pakistan.    The 
consultant will take the lead in the following: (i) conducting an IEE (if the IEE indicates that 
adverse impacts are likely, the consultant will prepare a detailed EIA); (ii) preparing sample 
IEEs (and, if necessary, EIAs) for the selected sample subprojects and will help the international 
environmental  specialist  develop  a  framework  for  IEE  (or  EIA)  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
environmental assessment guidelines (2003); and (iii) conducting the necessary fieldwork to 
assess  the  capability  of  the  IAs  to  conduct  IEEs  or  EIAs  and  implement  environmental 
management plans (EMPs). The consultant will also assist in the training course to be offered 
by the international environmental specialist. 
 
7.  Social Development Specialist (4.5 person-months) 
 
17.  The consultant will have significant experience in conducting S and IP analysis and 
involuntary resettlement plans in Pakistan.  The consultant will (i) take the lead in preparing 
sample S and IP analysis and involuntary resettlement plans (if necessary) for the selected 
sample subprojects and will also help the international social development specialist develop a 
framework S and IP plan and involuntary resettlement framework (if necessary); and (ii) will 
conduct the necessary fieldwork to assess the capability of the IAs to implement the framework 
S and IP plan and involuntary resettlement framework and assist in the training course to be 
provided by the international social development specialist. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
18.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report, 1 month after 
project start-up; (ii) an interim report with the findings of the required studies, analyses, models, 
and reports; and (iii) a final report that meets the requirements of ADB’s sector loan modality. 
 
19.  All major draft reports will be circulated to the IAs, ADB, and all stakeholders. The 
consultants will then organize a consultation or tripartite meeting of representatives from the 
IAs,  Alternative  Energy  Development  Board  (AEDB),  and  ADB,  and  other  concerned

Appendix 3  13 
stakeholders – concerned ministries, departments, and agencies of the federal and provincial 
governments, nongovernment organizations, private entrepreneurs, external funding agencies, 
etc.  The meetings will be held in Pakistan, 1 week after circulation of the draft reports, to 
discuss their findings. The team leader will submit a final report within 1 month of the final 
consultation or tripartite meeting, incorporating the comments at the meetings. 
 
20.  The team leader will submit three bound copies of each final report and two electronic 
copies on CD-ROM each to the IAs, AEDB and ADB.
